intro: Thelypodium integrifolium var. gracilipes, commonly known as the slenderleaf thelypodium, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of the western United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes familiar plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or rocky habitats. Its botanical features make it an important component of alpine and subalpine ecosystems.
